title: What is Dart?
content: Dart is a programming language developed by Google, mainly used with Flutter for building mobile, web, and desktop applications. It's designed to be easy to learn and use, with features like null safety, strong typing, and excellent performance.
definition: Dart is a client-optimized programming language for fast apps on any platform.
explanation: Dart was created by Google in 2011 and has evolved to become the primary language for Flutter development. It combines the best features of other languages like Java, C#, and JavaScript while adding its own unique capabilities.

title: Hello World Program
content: Every programming journey starts with a 'Hello World' program. In Dart, this is simple and straightforward using the print() function.
definition: A basic program that outputs 'Hello World' to demonstrate the fundamental structure of a Dart program.
explanation: The main() function is the entry point of every Dart program. It's where execution begins. The print() function displays text to the console.

title: Variables and Data Types
content: Variables are containers for storing data values. Dart supports several built-in data types including numbers, strings, booleans, and more.
definition: Variables are named storage locations that hold data of specific types.
explanation: Dart is a statically typed language, meaning variables have types that are known at compile time. You can use explicit type declarations or let Dart infer the type using 'var'.

title: Operators
content: Operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Dart supports arithmetic, relational, logical, and assignment operators.
definition: Operators are symbols that tell the compiler to perform specific mathematical or logical operations.
explanation: Dart provides a rich set of operators for different purposes. Understanding operators is crucial for writing effective Dart code.

title: Comments
content: Comments are lines of text that are ignored by the Dart compiler. They help document your code and make it more readable for other developers.
definition: Comments are non-executable text that explains what the code does.
explanation: Good commenting practices make code more maintainable and help other developers understand your logic. Dart supports both single-line and multi-line comments.
keyPoints: Use comments to explain complex logic

title: Conditional Statements
content: Conditional statements allow your program to make decisions based on different conditions. Dart supports if, else, and switch statements.
definition: Conditional statements execute different code blocks based on whether a condition is true or false.
explanation: Conditional statements are fundamental to programming as they allow programs to respond differently to different situations. They make programs dynamic and interactive.
keyPoints: if executes code when condition is true
else executes when condition is false
switch compares a variable to multiple values
break is needed in switch cases

title: Loops
content: Loops allow you to execute a block of code multiple times. Dart supports for, while, and do-while loops, as well as for-in loops for collections.
definition: Loops are control structures that repeat a block of code until a specified condition is met.
explanation: Loops are essential for performing repetitive tasks efficiently. They help reduce code duplication and make programs more efficient.
keyPoints: for loop: known number of iterations
Use break to exit loops early

title: Defining Functions
content: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They help organize code and make it more modular and maintainable.
definition: A function is a block of code that performs a specific task and can be called from other parts of the program.
explanation: Functions are fundamental building blocks in Dart. They allow you to break down complex problems into smaller, manageable pieces. Functions can take parameters and return values.

title: Parameters
content: Parameters allow functions to receive data from the calling code. Dart supports different types of parameters including positional, named, and optional parameters.
definition: Parameters are variables that receive values when a function is called.
explanation: Parameters make functions flexible and reusable. Dart offers several ways to pass parameters, each with its own advantages for different use cases.

title: Lists (Arrays)
content: Lists are ordered collections of objects. They are similar to arrays in other languages and are one of the most commonly used data structures in Dart.
definition: A List is an ordered collection of objects where each object can be accessed by its index position.
explanation: Lists in Dart are dynamic and can grow or shrink in size. They can contain objects of any type, but it's common to use them with a specific type for better performance and type safety.

title: Sets
content: Sets are unordered collections of unique objects. They are useful when you need to store unique values and don't care about the order.
definition: A Set is an unordered collection of unique objects where each object appears only once.
explanation: Sets are particularly useful for removing duplicates from lists, checking membership, and performing set operations like union, intersection, and difference.

title: Maps (Key-Value pairs)
content: Maps are collections of key-value pairs where each key is unique. They are similar to dictionaries in Python or objects in JavaScript.
definition: A Map is a collection of key-value pairs where each key maps to exactly one value.
explanation: Maps are extremely useful for storing and retrieving data using meaningful keys instead of numeric indices. They provide fast lookup times and are perfect for representing structured data.
